The kernel ensures optional tensors (e.g., bias) are explicitly placed on the correct device to avoid device synchronization or memory access errors.
The kernel checks both tensor definition status and element count (bias.defined() && bias.numel() > 0) to properly handle empty tensors and avoid invalid memory accesses.
The kernel uses device-aware placeholder tensors (same device/dtype as input) for optional parameters instead of default CPU tensors to prevent device mismatch overhead.
